questions.question: What is the molecular structure of the dicopper(I) complex 1'@?
questions.answer: The dicopper(I) complex 1'@ contains two peripheral 30-membered rings separately interlocked with a central 44-membered ring.

questions.question: How does the molecular structure of 1'@ differ from its initial representation in Figure 1?
questions.answer: The molecular structure of 1'@ is strikingly different from the structure shown in Figure 1, with a globular shape that is evident from the view given on the cover of the issue.

questions.question: What experimental techniques were used to study the structure of 1'@?
questions.answer: Both crystallographic study and an NMR solution study were used to examine the structure of 1'@.

questions.question: What does the close proximity of the two copper(I) complex subunits in 1'@ indicate?
questions.answer: The close proximity of the two copper(I) complex subunits in 1'@ could be detected independently of the crystallographic study by 'H-NMR solution measurements, indicating a curled-up conformation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the NOE difference spectrum observed in the 'H-NMR study of 1'@?
questions.answer: The NOE difference spectrum observed in the 'H-NMR study of 1'@ confirms the curled-up conformation of the central ring, as it shows a clear Overhauser effect between hydrogen atoms of the 44-membered ring and the peripheral rings.

questions.question: How does the geometry of the 2,9-diphenyl-1,10-phenanthroline (dpp) subunits vary between the different types of rings in 1'@?
questions.answer: In the 44-membered ring B, no distortion is observed in the dpp subunits, whereas in the peripheral rings A and C, the phen nucleus is nonplanar and the dpp fragment undergoes a noticeable pinching.

questions.question: What led to the synthesis of [3]-catenanes and how do they differ from [3]-catenates?
questions.answer: The templating properties of transition metals were taken advantage of for interlocking coordinating acyclic leading to catenands after demetalation of the corresponding catenates. [3]-Catenanes consist of three interlocked rings and have been synthesized by Schill et al., while [3]-catenates have been prepared by using an oxidative coupling of terminal diynes.

questions.question: How does the molecular structure of 1'@ contribute to its stability in solution?
questions.answer: The curled-up geometry of 1'@ and the internal stacking observed contribute to its stability in solution, reminiscent of systems consisting of a cationic noble-metal complex linked to a large macrocyclic polyether which has to fold up to adjust its geometry to the shape of the bound transition-metal complex.

questions.question: What role do the diacetylenic chains play in the structure of 1'@?
questions.answer: The diacetylenic chains in 1'@ are parallel to one another and located 10.5 A apart, contributing to the structural integrity and specific geometry of the molecule.

questions.question: How does the conformational change upon complexation affect the molecular shapes of catenates and catenands?
questions.answer: The conformational change upon complexation results in dramatically different molecular shapes for catenates and catenands, with a complete conformational change of the molecule taking place upon complexation.

questions.question: What evidence supports the notion that the molecular shapes of 1'@ in the solid state and in solution are analogous?
questions.answer: The analogy between the molecular shapes in the solid state and in solution is confirmed by the observation of a nuclear Overhauser effect (NOE) between hydrogen atoms of the 44-membered ring and the peripheral rings, indicating similar molecular conformations in both states.

questions.question: How does the folding up of the central ring B in 1'@ affect its overall molecular shape?
questions.answer: The folding up of the central ring B in 1'@ results in a boatlike shape and contributes to the globular overall molecular shape of the molecule.

questions.question: Is the molecular structure of 1'@ maintained in solution?
questions.answer: True. The molecular structure of 1'@, including its curled-up geometry and internal stacking, is stable enough to be maintained in solution.

questions.question: Does the 'H-NMR spectrum of 1'@ indicate the presence of three dpp fragments?
questions.answer: False. The 'H-NMR spectrum of 1'@ indicates the presence of two dpp fragments entwined around a link.

questions.question: Are the coordination polyhedra around the copper atoms in 1'@ equivalent?
questions.answer: False. The coordination polyhedra around the copper atoms in 1'@ are not equivalent.

questions.question: Is the average torsion angle of the phenyl rings in 1'@ less than 20 degrees?
questions.answer: False. The average torsion angle of the phenyl rings in 1'@ is 43 degrees.

questions.question: Does the crystallographic study of 1'@ utilize X-ray diffraction?
questions.answer: True. The crystallographic study of 1'@ was determined by X-ray diffraction.

questions.question: Are the peripheral rings A and C in 1'@ positioned in a perpendicular fashion to the central ring?
questions.answer: False. The peripheral rings A and C in 1'@ are placed as bracelets in an approximately parallel fashion to the central ring.

questions.question: Is the distance between the copper(I) centers in 1'@ more than 10 A?
questions.answer: False. The copper(I) centers in 1'@ are only 8.0 A apart.
